title: 115_hr1619
content: The Act titled "Stop Iran From Smuggling Weapons to Terrorists Act" authorizes assistance and training to enhance maritime security in countries bordering the Persian Gulf, Arabian Sea, or Mediterranean Sea. The Act authorizes assistance and training to increase maritime security in countries bordering the Persian Gulf, Arabian Sea, or Mediterranean Sea to deter illicit smuggling and Iranian weapons shipments. The Secretary of Defense, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, is authorized to provide training to military and security forces of specific countries with maritime security missions. The Counter Iran Maritime Initiative authorizes training for military and security forces in countries bordering the Persian Gulf, Arabian Sea, or Mediterranean Sea to deter illicit smuggling and Iranian weapons shipments. Training includes de minimis equipment, supplies, and promoting human rights and respect for civilian authority. The Counter Iran Maritime Initiative authorizes training for military and security forces in countries bordering the Persian Gulf, Arabian Sea, or Mediterranean Sea to deter illicit smuggling and Iranian weapons shipments. $50,000,000 from the fiscal year 2018 budget is allocated for assistance and training, with a focus on cost-sharing agreements to offset training costs. The Secretary of Defense, with the concurrence of the Secretary of State, will negotiate a cost-sharing agreement with recipient countries for training costs. The agreement must include terms determined by the Secretary of Defense, with a minimum cost-sharing of 50%. The portion of cost-sharing received may be credited towards Defense-wide activities appropriations. The Secretary of Defense must notify Congress 15 days before exercising training authority with a recipient country. The Secretary of Defense must submit a notification to Congress regarding the recipient country, justification for training program, budget details, implementation timeline, and sustainment arrangements. The Secretary of Defense must provide Congress with details on the recipient country's sustainment of developed capabilities, funding sources for sustainment efforts, program objectives, assessment framework for capability development, and other relevant matters. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific Senate and House committees. Assistance and training under this section will end on September 30, 2021.
